awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Control and Sensitivity Analysis for Fluid-Elasticity Interactions and Fluid-Solid Mixtures
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important biological and physical problems involve either the interaction of a fluid with an elastic body, or the flow of a fluid through a deformable, porous medium.  These problems are known as fluid-structure interactions and fluid-solid mixture problems, respectively.  In most of these applications, the ultimate goal is the optimization or optimal control of the considered process, as well as related sensitivity analysis (with respect to relevant physical/biological parameters) investigations. Examples include the design of small-scale unmanned aircrafts and morphing aircraft wings, like robo-bees, minimizing turbulence in blood flow within a stenosed or stented artery, or optimizing the pressure of the blood flow and investigating the influence of pertinent biological parameters in the case of the lamina cribrosa in the eye, where these factors are believed to be related to the development of glaucoma.  This research program addresses sensitivity analysis, control, and optimization-related problems for moving boundary fluid-elasticity interactions and fluid flows through biological tissues.  The project will focus on the particular example of the coupling between biomechanics and hemodynamics in the lamina cribrosa in the eye, where performing sensitivity analysis with respect to important parameters (like blood flow and intraocular and retrolaminar pressures) will further the understanding of the cause and progression of glaucoma, and enable novel means for preventing or treating glaucoma. This research will also be applicable to other biological fluid-solid mixtures such as cartilages, bones, and engineered tissues. 

Moving boundary fluid-elasticity interactions and  porous media flows are nonlinear dynamical systems with Banach space parameters, and most questions related to their sensitivity analysis and control are open in the field. This project will (i) advance the theory of optimal control problems subject to these nonlinear systems by developing the theoretical framework for sensitivity analysis and optimality conditions;  (ii) perform sensitivity analysis on the lamina cribrosa model to identify the important biological parameters, and use the obtained results to develop and address possible control strategies in the development of glaucoma. Well-posedness of optimal solutions, Frechet differentiability of cost functionals and state  with respect to both distributed and boundary controls, and derivation and well-posedness analysis of adjoint systems will be addressed.  These results will provide the starting point for all sensitivity calculations, parameter estimation, and derivative-based optimization algorithms.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ele.pgm_ele_name: Proc Sys, Reac Eng & Mol Therm

por.por_cntn:
1. Intellectual Merit : This project addressed several open questions related to fluid-elasticity interactions and fluid-solid mixtures, particularly in the context of biomechanics and engineering. Key contributions are summarized below:

-Nonlinear Poro-(Visco)-Elastic Models: The research developed new well-posedness results for nonlinear poro-(visco)-elastic models, crucial for understanding the behavior of biological tissues like articular cartilage and the lamina cribrosa in the eye. These models incorporated dilation-dependent permeability, a significant advancement over prior models that assumed constant permeability. The findings enhanced understanding of disease mechanisms in glaucoma and treatment strategies, aligning with experimental results in glaucoma, osteoporosis, and Alzheimer’s disease.

- Sensitivity Analysis and Control: Sensitivity analysis was conducted for these nonlinear poroelastic models to optimize control strategies in fluid-solid mixtures. It demonstrated that boundary conditions on solid structures have a more pronounced impact on fluid behavior than direct controls. This insight is pivotal for effective control in medical and engineering applications. Additionally, a dimensional analysis identified parameters that could help design structural properties and experimental conditions to limit fluid velocity, thereby preventing potential tissue damage.

- Optimal control problems subject to fluid flows through deformable, porous media:  The objective is to regulate solid displacement and fluid pressure using distributed and boundary controls. Existence, uniqueness, and characterization of optimal control through first-order optimality conditions were established for convex optimization problems constrained by linear porelastic and poro-visco-elastic systems. Integer control problems governed by fluid flow through deformable porous media were also investigated.

- Multilayered Poroelasticity Interactions: The research also explored fluid-poroelastic structure interactions (FPSI) where multilayered structures, like those found in arterial walls or bioartificial organs, interact with fluid flows. New weak solutions were established for coupled systems involving dynamic Stokes flow and poroelastic media, overcoming challenges related to interface regularity and nonlinearity. A uniqueness criteria was also provided.

- Free/Moving Boundary Fluid-Structure Interactions: The project extended theories of well-posedness, control, and optimization in free/moving boundary fluid-structure interaction (FSI) problems. The PI's work advanced the understanding of fluid turbulence minimization and feedback stabilization in these systems, which are prevalent in biomechanics and aerodynamics.

The project's results contribute substantially to applied mathematics and control theory. Given the complexity and broad applicability of the PDE systems explored, the PI’s strategies, techniques, and findings hold significant relevance across the fields of mathematics, physics, engineering, biology, and medicine. 

The PI gave 66 invited presentations and her graduate students gave 26 talks on results related to this project at national and international conferences.

 

2. Broader Impacts:  The project had significant broader impacts, both in the scientific community and in public engagement:

- Graduate and Undergraduate Education: The PI supervised four Ph.D. students who completed theses related to the project, with graduates securing academic and research positions at prominent institutions. Undergraduate and master's students were also engaged through research projects.

- Outreach and Public Engagement: The PI organized multiple outreach programs to promote STEM education and mathematics literacy:

(i) Math Doesn't Bug Me: This program, part of the annual festival BugFest at the  NC Museum of Natural Sciences  in Raleigh, NC (2016-2019), reached over 25,000 visitors in 2019 alone, fostering interest in mathematics through hands-on activities.

(ii) GAMMA (Girls in Applied Math, Modeling, and Analysis): This program, held at NC State University in 2017, 2022, and 2023, inspired high school girls to explore math-related careers through career panels and interactive activities focused on applied math. 

(iii) Games in Applied Math, Modeling, and Analysis: Held in 2024 at NC State University, this program introduced high school students to control and optimization through interactive games and activities.

These outreach programs have contributed to diversifying the next generation of STEM students and increasing public understanding of the role of mathematics in science and engineering.

The models and methods developed in this project offer novel insights into biological processes and provide a foundation for further exploration in related fields. 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2024
Modified by: Lorena V Bociu
